Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to the Research Division Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Division.

3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy syrup? 10 lbs. Bags.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $5.00 per cwt.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwards Syrup.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.

At what price? $0.40 each.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

Did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Milking cows, cream, butter.

Butter? Made at home.

What was the price of butter? $0.75 lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese? American, cheddar, mozzarella.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, Bacon.

How did you get fresh meat? Killed our own.

How often did you get fresh meat? Every fall & winter, daily.

How did you preserve meat? Canned at home.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so, what was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Wild Turkey.

For how long? 1901-1912.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Salmon, cod, haddock.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh, whole fish.

Kinds? Salmon, cod, haddock.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? ...Black tea.

At what price? $1.00/lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? $1.00/lb.

What other beverages did you buy?

7. VEGETABLES AND FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel then? $2.50/bushel.

Could you get potatoes at that time?

If not, where from?

That year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of 1940-41?

Potatoes Carrots Turnips Beets Cabbage

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 2 lbs.

How did you buy prunes? (in bulk or by the box)? By the box.

What weight? 1 lb.

How did the greater handle prunes (by box)? 8 lbs.

What was the price of prunes? $1.00/lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by canning?

Peas? Beans? Corn? Saskatoons?

Other foods?

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1940-41.

That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1940-41.

That year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1940-41.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?

To what extent?

Did you take your own gardens?

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Where did you get your fuel? Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Did you use an outdoor fireplace or take oven? (Give dates)

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers used with the food you purchased (give dates where possible). The gradual change from cardboard boxes, jars, to modern wrapping has been spread over many years in an attempt to quiet specific desires. When I first started up near 1948-49, we used to acquire farm grown goods in burlap bags.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge 2 cups, Toast 2 slices (Homemade) Butter 1 pat, Brownie 1 piece, Two boiled eggs, Bread & Butter or Poi Salad, Tea, Soup, broth or soup, Cheese, canned or fresh fruit, tea,

18. First year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1948?

List those present and give their approximate ages at the time:
Mary 27, wife 22, + 3 children.

Turkey, Plum Pudding, nuts & raisins offered.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No, never lived as well in my life as now in Medicine Hat, Alberta, all the food I want fresh, grown by a local, home raised anything!
26. WRAPPINGS AND GIFTS THERE.

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers used with the food you purchased (give dates where possible). The gradual change from Barke, Boner, Jars, to modern aluminum cans spread over the years in an attempt to quiet the noise when food packed up went into the cupboard.

27. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge 2 cups, Toast browned & buttered, Butter.

Lunch: Soup or Pudding, Two Beets, Bread & Butter, Tea.

Supper: Meat or Fish, Cheese, Carrots or Parsnips, Rice.

28. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1948.

Give the name. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time:

Margaret 27, Wife 22, + 3 children.

Turkey, Peas, Pudding, Biscuits & Rainier Coffee.

29. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. How hard do you think life would have been in hotels, restaurants etc., all the food was fresh, home grown & a quality, unskilled anyway.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today. Have any changes been made?

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, proper bins or storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.) We need returning all Ballard, Okanagan, Ash, Mary, and other satisfactory range for re-packing. We need as many to put into farming but not enough. We must establish how much is cheaper away buying in bulk without establishing on an quality & good eating for our use. It can stand, however, direct market competition in modern markets during harvest time. Ballard will be the first to fill the void.

S.J. Bigg
